description:
Transfer student Takisawa Noboru quickly learns that all disputes at his new school are settled in the boxing ring. Now he finds himself in a series of showdowns with the local top dog, Ibuki Saburo, for the love and respect of the beautiful Yukari.

(Source: Anime News Network)

tags.name: Parody
tags.description: Features deliberate exaggeration of popular tropes or a particular genre to comedic effect.

tags.name: Boxing
tags.description: Centers around the sport of boxing.

tags.name: Slapstick
tags.description: Prominently features comedy based on deliberately clumsy actions or embarrassing events.

tags.name: Primarily Teen Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of teen characters.

tags.name: Shounen
tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult males.

tags.name: School
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a primary or secondary educational institution.

tags.name: Bullying
tags.description: Prominently features the use of force for intimidation, often in a school setting.

tags.name: Love Triangle
tags.description: Centered around romantic feelings between more than two people. Includes all love polygons.

tags.name: Martial Arts
tags.description: Centers around the use of traditional hand-to-hand combat.

node.description: [Twitter](https://twitter.com/simakazu)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/森山雄治) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yuji_Moriyama) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/77356964)

Yuuji Moriyama is a director, animator and character designer.

Moriyama started helping out with in-between animation when he was a student at Kanto Daiichi High School. After graduating from high school, he joined Studio Musashi, which was recruiting staff through newspaper ads. His first work as an official in-betweener was for [Wakusei Robo Danguard Ace](https://anilist.co/anime/1986/). He then moved to Studio Cockpit, where he worked on [Galaxy Express 999](https://anilist.co/anime/1491/), before moving on to NeoMedia. There he worked on [Trider G7](https://anilist.co/anime/4536/), [Doraemon](https://anilist.co/anime/2471/), and [Belle and Sebastian](https://anilist.co/anime/3836/). With Trider G7, he was promoted from in-between to key animation. He left NeoMedia in 1982 to work as a freelancer, starting with [Combat Mecha Xabungle](https://anilist.co/anime/2254/) and [Makyou Densetsu Acrobunch](https://anilist.co/anime/3880/).

The popular anime [Urusei Yatsura](https://anilist.co/anime/1293/), in which he participated from the same year, was Moriyama's breakthrough work. With this series, he made his debut as an animation director and storyboard artist, and was in charge of the opening animation for the first time, joining a group of popular animators overnight. Chief director [Mamoru Oshii](https://anilist.co/staff/99097/), who was responsible for Urusei Yatsura, expected him to become a partner, so Moriyama tried his hand at manga as well by illustrating a manga written by Oshii that was serialized in the Animage magazine in 1984 called Todo no Tsumari. After the end of Urusei Yatsura, he was selected as a character designer for the later series [Maison Ikkoku](https://anilist.co/anime/1453/), and has since been in charge of character design for many other works. In 1987, he won the 4th Japan Anime Awards in the Animation Director category. After that, he shifted from animating to directing.
After that he participated in many works, mainly Chaos Project , Studio Pierrot , and Studio Hibari and then has seated at Studio Hibari's Lerche. 

Moriyama often works under one of his many pen-names.
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/岩浪美和) | [Twitter](https://x.com/i/user/169097071)

Best known as the creator of [Project A-Ko](https://anilist.co/anime/212/). He is particularly noted for his work during the ‘80s, going all out in [Urusei Yatsura](https://anilist.co/anime/1293/) and many OVAs and films such as [Outlanders](https://anilist.co/anime/1940/) and [Dirty Pair](https://anilist.co/anime/1796/). He is among the many [Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/)-influenced animators of the ‘80s, and his work is recognizable from its wide-eyed characters, attention to anatomical detail, and characterful impact frames.

Initially he wanted to be a mangaka, but enrolled in university instead after not being sure if he could make a living - though, he did drop out after a year. During his short lived time there, he was watching [Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/80/) and had sent a letter to [Yoshiyuki Tomino](https://anilist.co/staff/97337/) with the hopes of joining [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/). They weren’t accepting in-betweeners at this time, so a producer of theirs referred him to [Studio Live](https://anilist.co/studio/6460/), which he then joined after passing an entrance test in 1979. There he studied under the studio’s founder, [Toyoo Ashida](https://anilist.co/staff/110953/), and started gaining attention for his work on Urusei Yatsura.

After working at [Studio Deen](https://anilist.co/studio/37/) for a while, he took part in the establishment of Studio Graviton alongside [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/), [Shouichi Masuo](https://anilist.co/staff/133909/) and [Kouji Itou](https://anilist.co/staff/101166/). He then went freelance and worked regularly for [Studio Fantasia](https://anilist.co/studio/24/).

Lately he has shifted more and more towards directing and storyboarding rather than animating himself, often collaborating with his long-time friends [Yuuji Moriyama](https://anilist.co/staff/100658/) and [Noriyasu Yamauchi](https://anilist.co/staff/112903/).

__Nickname:__ オタキング (Otaking)

[YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC0FFHRF1mytLDhs6nxqGIQg) | [niconico](https://ch.nicovideo.jp/ex) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/ToshioOkada) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/frex.otaking) | [Official Blog](http://blog.livedoor.jp/okada_toshio/) | [Profile (Yoshimoto Kogyo)](https://profile.yoshimoto.co.jp/talent/detail?id=3516) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toshio_Okada) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%B2%A1%E7%94%B0%E6%96%97%E5%8F%B8%E5%A4%AB)

Okada Toshio is an anime producer, author, lecturer and the co-founder and former president of Gainax, which he left in 1992. He has written several Japanese-language books on otaku culture and lectured on the topic as an adjunct instructor at Tokyo University. He is considered the foremost authority on otaku and has been crowned "OtaKing" amongst his colleagues and fellow otaku.

(Source: AniDB)

He currently runs a popular YouTube channel [OTAKING](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC0FFHRF1mytLDhs6nxqGIQg) discussing otaku culture. He runs weekly paid seminars on his NicoNico & YouTube channels.

__Nickname:__ オタキング (Otaking)

[YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC0FFHRF1mytLDhs6nxqGIQg) | [niconico](https://ch.nicovideo.jp/ex) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/ToshioOkada) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/frex.otaking) | [Official Blog](http://blog.livedoor.jp/okada_toshio/) | [Profile (Yoshimoto Kogyo)](https://profile.yoshimoto.co.jp/talent/detail?id=3516) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toshio_Okada) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%B2%A1%E7%94%B0%E6%96%97%E5%8F%B8%E5%A4%AB)

Okada Toshio is an anime producer, author, lecturer and the co-founder and former president of Gainax, which he left in 1992. He has written several Japanese-language books on otaku culture and lectured on the topic as an adjunct instructor at Tokyo University. He is considered the foremost authority on otaku and has been crowned "OtaKing" amongst his colleagues and fellow otaku.

(Source: AniDB)

He currently runs a popular YouTube channel [OTAKING](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC0FFHRF1mytLDhs6nxqGIQg) discussing otaku culture. He runs weekly paid seminars on his NicoNico & YouTube channels.

[Takuya Suzuki](https://anilist.co/staff/151685/)'s brother.

_Note: Not to be confused with [Tatsuya Suzuki (鈴木辰也)](https://anilist.co/staff/225169/)._

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/kenokun)

Kouhei attended Tokyo National University of Fine Arts and Music (Music Faculty, Composition Department), studying under Tomojirou Ikenouchi and other professors. He worked for three consecutive years at Victor Music Industries after he graduated from the University. He attended Berklee College of Music for two years after he left Victor Music Industries. After returning to Japan, Kouhei started his activities as a composer.

Though Kouhei had been playing at the hotel at first, he was requested to compose an insert song for "Arcadia of My Youth: Endless Orbit SSX", a 1982 TV anime, and it became his first work as a composer. Afterwards, he handled some more compositions of insert songs, this time for the Super Sentai series and he also did the composition of the background music for a TV anime, Konpora Kid, in 1985.

Notably, the score for [Top wo Nerae! Gunbuster](https://anilist.co/anime/949/) made his name and talent very famous among anime fans, and is recognized as one of his most important works. He also handled the composition of [Top wo Nerae 2! Diebuster](https://anilist.co/anime/1002/) and showed a peculiar arrangement, which he added to his previous 17-year-old work. Another of his most important work is often said to be [Yuusha-Ou GaoGaiGar](https://anilist.co/anime/890/), and the [sequel](https://anilist.co/anime/1382/) following it.

In 2002, he won the first Tokyo Anime Award for Best Music for his work on [Overman King Gainer](https://anilist.co/anime/1792/).

Shuuichi Kakesu was born 1957 in Chiba Prefecture, Japan. He is a graduate student of Japan Academy of Moving Images and the founder and current representative director of editing studio Jay Film.

He started working at editing studio Okayasu Promotion, where he studied under Okayasu Hajime himself. In 1990 he founded Jay Film; or reorganised Kakesu Henshuushitsu, an editing studio he founded previously, into Jay Film. He was the first to introduce the non-linear editing system in Japan in 1994.

Kakesu won an Association of Media in Digital Award in 1996.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/murahama)

After graduating from school he took social sciences at Otemon Gakuin University, where he belonged to the local SF club. During his time at university he participated in Daicon Film activities and after dropping out of university in 1987 he joined the former Daicon Film, now Gainax, where he participated as Production Manager in works such as Honneamise, Nadia and Top wo Nerae.

In 1992 he left together with Maeda Mahiro, Higuchi Shinji and Yamaguchi Hiroshi to establish a new studio, Gonzo, where he assumed the position of President and Representative Director. Currently he serves as Chairman of the Board and Representative Director at GDH.

Murahama left Gonzo on March 31, 2009 and launched a new company called Lambda Film on April 1, 2009, the same day that Gozo's parent company, GDH, absorbed Gonzo and adopted the Gonzo brand name for itself.

Murahama will serve as the representative director for Lambda Film's board of directors.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/ohnuma1955)

Hiroyuki Oonuma is a writer, screenwriter, editor and planner. He was born in Sendai, the capital of Miyagi Prefecture.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/fantasia_iizuka)

Tomohisa Iizuka is a producer and planner for anime. He served as the representative director of Studio Fantasia until it went bankrupt in 2016. Before that he worked in the finishing section of Tsuchida Production as colour designer.

Iizuka founded the animation company Studio Fantasia, when he was still an employee of Tsuchida Production, on October 12, 1983 which was three years before Tsuchida Production collapsed into bankruptcy.
Sadafumi Sano is a director of photography.
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/渡辺純央)
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/渡辺純央)
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/nagairumiko)
Originating from [Tatsunoko Production](https://anilist.co/studio/103/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/岡村天斎) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tensai_Okamura)

During his university days at Waseda University, Okamura was a part of Waseda's manga research society and together with other budding animators, produced his first independent anime there. Upon graduating from university, Okamura joined the animation production studio Madhouse as an animator through the recommendation of a friend. Lensman was the first series he worked on as an animator. The first anime movies that he worked on were Kamui no Ken and Bobby ni Kubittake. 

In 1989, he made his debut as an episode director with Yawara! and soon made his full directorial debut in 1995 with Memories. He later left Madhouse and went freelance, working on several projects along the way.

In 1991, he changed his first name from Yutaka to Tensai.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/asakonishida) | [Pixiv](https://www.pixiv.net/en/users/24387) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/西田亜沙子)

Originating from Studio Muu.


Married to fellow animator [Seiichi Nakatani](https://anilist.co/staff/107409/Seiichi-Nakatani).
